title: The amount of unbalanced matches is pathetic
body:
You can tell way less players are playing ranked.  And why should they play?  Too much damage, too snowbally, some champs are too stupid,  not all ranged adcs are strong, too many dumb reworks, making supports boring to play like in hots, and the list goes on...

Why play so long with unbalanced matches when you can get unbalanced matches on hots but lose a lot faster?

Also,  a lot of players  has no idea when and when not to engage.

> Also,  a lot of players  has no idea when and when not to engage.


it's almost like they promised to give us a better tutorial 10 years ago and never really delivered so many of the core mechanics of the game aren't even noticed by most players until some stoned streamer finally points it out (like Solorenektontop) and the silver players and lower (Over50% of the player population) are like "OHHHHHH ok lemme climb up 6 ranks real quick"

People should be able to learn on their own. And how do you expect Riot to give a good tutorial when to engage and when not to? It's very situational and depends on circumstances, not to mention that Rito probably doesn't have people good enough at the game working for them.

I mean you can start with tutorials on shit like wave control and tower plates

They don't explain anything in the tutorial other than that zero item miss fortune can 1v3 under enemy tower

And i hate that "They should be able to learn on their own" because it's a load of shit. You don't say that to a fucking electrician, you give him an apprenticeship so he doesn't go fucking up houses. Learning how to improvise, learning more in depth tactics sure. But learning all the core mechanics, like "Lethality vs squishies, %pen vs tanks" or concepts approaching team composition, counter picking, etc. 

In addition you could commission the best players (Some intersection of games played vs rank) in each champ community to help craft tutorials for champions that could be as long as is needed to fully master a champion.

Open ai bots for "Hard bots" mode that learn from a player and try to abuse their weaknesses would be great as sort of a practice tool.

all these are off the cuff ideas but there are a billion things riot could teach that would probably lead to less toxicity at lower ranks due to people just not getting basic concepts like "Supports don't compete for farm in lane phase"

how about a system where players can coach players of two ranks down in exchange for more blue essence.. so like a gold player could coach a bronze player, and a silver player could coach an iron player. Would be great both to help people who are just missing something because they just don't realize it. Also would be a great way to meet new players

You don't seems to understand what I've said. There is **no way** for **anyone** to make an easy to understand and comprehensive guide for when to engage and when not to. Even tips from high level players can only go so far. Some people might decide to religiously follow this tips, for example, even in the few situations when they don't apply. 

If high level player could make guides that worked well then, logically, duo-ing with high level player should easily allow you to learn by observing their gameplay. But you often see ppl duo-ing with higher ranked players and climbing, then falling back down on their own, having learned nothing.

It all comes down to talent experience, some ppl are slower to learn, some faster, some have a natural talent for this and some people will **never** be able to learn. And, more often than not, it's because of their attitude and and arrogance.
Dude just make Solorenekton only be Clippy and he just pops up being helpful going "BEWM WHADDUP SOLORENEKTONONLY HERE LOOKS LIKE YOU NEED SOME HELP"

I don't endorse Rito's management of the game. But neither do I support blaming them for things that aren't actually their fault.

"Forging a better Runes system first means concentrating the system's power into fewer choices so that each selection matters more."

When they released runes reforged, the first sentence was this. They honestly believe that removing diversity and creativity in how you play was a good idea and have stuck with this design philosophy since. 

Runes reforged was a bad idea when it came out, and they have done nothing but prove me right every single new update. 

Too much damage because everyone got base stat increases to account for losing old runes, where you had the option of going more damage, tanky, sustain, gold generation, etc... They made nearly every keystone be "do this and get extra damage" as well as making nearly every minor rune be "have some more damage" or "have some more cdr/mana for more damage". Also, too much mobility because Relentless hunter giving every assassin +55 BASE movement speed out of combat just for existing.

"Unlike basic attacks, no two abilities are the same, which makes the stat wildly variable in value.This means that it’s functionally impossible to make spell vamp work the way you’d expect, and it instead operates on myriad edge-cases to avoid feeling abusive and unintuitive."

Hey guys welcome to runes reforged, we added this rune called Ravenous hunter that does something kind of cool, you will heal for a percentage of the damage dealt by your abilities by 14%. Also it's a minor rune in the strongest rune tree.

We are going to keep Death's Dance because that lets you heal for 15% of your TOTAL damage dealt, unlike spell vamp that only heals for damage from abilities, because that is toxic for the game.
Yeah, as someone who doesn't have a fortune to throw at the game, I prefer not having to buy 100 rune pages to be able to play any champ I want. The old system was awful just because of this.
It's just a game of gimmicks now. Honestly feels like a mobile game

That is rather the point.  If someone is a well established Plat, Diamond, or Masters+ player in solo queue, assigning them a provisional rank of Silver is inane.  

And perhaps you missed the fact that this was happening _consistently_.   If it was just a rare or occasional occurrence, I (and I am sure many others) wouldn't have a problem with it.  Sadly, it is not rare or occasional but ubiquitous.  Trying to climb through a lower rank while consistently facing much higher ranked competition and not being rewarded for it feels incredibly bad.   I mean if I was gaining huge gobs of Elo when I actually won against diamonds and losing next to nothing for getting rolled by a Masters player, it wouldn't be so bad.   But I even played a match where there was a **1500** Elo difference in teams and lost 20 lp for it.  That is just completely stupid, broken design.
